dialogue: Look at this bar. All eight parts are shaded. Why does 8/8 equal 1?
prompt: Why is 8/8 the same as 1 whole?

options.text: We have all the parts, so it makes a complete whole
Because it has the most parts

correct_answer.context: When all parts of a whole are present (8 out of 8), they combine to make one complete whole

success_path_dialogue: Exactly. When you have all the parts, you have one complete whole.

steps.dialogue: Not quite. Think about what happens when you have all the parts of something.

Let's think about this together. Look at the bar - it's divided into 8 equal parts, and all 8 parts are shaded. When you have every single part of something, what do you have? Think about what it means to have all the pieces.

Let me help you understand why 8/8 equals 1. The bar shows 8 equal parts, and all 8 of those parts are shaded. The key idea is this: when you have all the parts of a whole - every single piece - you have one complete whole. It doesn't matter if it's 8/8, 3/3, or 5/5. When the numerator and denominator are the same, you have all the parts, which means you have 1 whole. That's why 8/8 equals 1.
